Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: Electronic Security and Privacy: Technological, Human, Enterprise and Legal Considerations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) award aims to make scientific, technological and educational advances in Electronic Security and Privacy (ESP). Intellectual Merit: Advances in information technologies and social media have been accompanied by a parallel increase in online threats in the form of cyber-attacks, on-line fraud and identity theft. The technological solutions that have been proposed to address the ESP problems have not been very effective as they have often been divorced from human, social, economic and legal considerations. The UIC IGERT program addresses this critical need by creating a comprehensive research and educational program that integrates faculty expertise from diverse fields: computer science and engineering, social and behavioral sciences, business, law and public policy. Building on this combined expertise, the program will create a cross-disciplinary, collaborative research and educational platform for training graduate students to address the challenges in electronic security and privacy.

Broader Impacts: The University of Illinois at Chicago?s IGERT program is transformative in its integration of technological, legal, enterprise and public policy perspectives in electronic security and privacy education and training. The advances made in this program will have an immediate impact on millions of individuals who use digital technologies and the Web. The program will create a talent pool of scientists and technologists, thus addressing the critical gap in the technology workforce needs of the nation. Through recruitment and retention of trainees from under-represented and minority groups, this program will also promote diversity in higher education.

IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project supported the research and training of 24 Ph.D. students over its life. These students and the associated faculty produced several hundreds of publications, conference presentations, and book chapters in interdisciplinary research. The project's research extended several fields of knowledge, summarized below:

  • Program safety and vulnerability detection and exploit generation
  • Cybercrime and malware 
  • Building reliable software and operating systems
  • Formal methods applied to security problems
  • Security and Privacy aspects of medical data, especially that of marginalized populations
  •  Ethics and public policy and technology
  • Legal aspects of Security and Privacy and Public Policy
  • Communication and privacy issues on social media and healthcare environments. 
  • Media portrayal of privacy and security issues

 Education in cybersecurity:  This was made possible by a continuous discussion among students and their advisors belonging to different disciplines. Overall, the project supported this work, which led to the production of hundreds of publications and presentations in conferences, and several journal articles and book chapters. Thanks to the work of this project, several patents were filed in the field of cyber-attack detection and secure mobile banking. Seven students trained from the project obtained faculty offers in US universities and abroad, and some obtained research positions in the technology sector as well. 

Overall, this project resulted in effective training of students who were able to appreciate that cybersecurity and privacy are complex, multi-faceted problems. Their training also imparted skills in designing  solutions based on research that increasingly relied on interdisciplinary approaches.
